evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of procedural deviation in pushback execution for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t1_early is robust against alternative explanations or counter-evidence.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation aligns with key features identified in pushback operations for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA, specifically during the 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t1_early period.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and documented during the early phase of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as per hist_dynamic_und_t1_early scope.

assumptions: The communication described in H1-H3 is representative of the overall crew coordination during the early phase.
The incident of the aircraft moving beyond the TRP (H4) is linked causally to communication/coordination breakdown.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing the incident, or if the incident was caused by procedural deviation rather than communication breakdown.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 shows active communication and coordination attempts among crew and tug operators, while H4-H5 document the event of the aircraft moving beyond the stop point, indicating a breakdown in coordination consistent with the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in whether the continued movement beyond TRP was due to communication failure or procedural deviation.

node.statement: The root cause of communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including timing, crew interactions, and operational context within hist_dynamic_und_t1_early.

assumptions: Crew interactions described imply communication/coordination issues
Operational context within hist_dynamic_und_t1_early is adequately represented by the provided history items
defeaters: If evidence showed clear environmental or marking deficiencies causing the event
If hardware or mechanical failures were documented as primary causes
If procedural deviations unrelated to communication were the main factor
